## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Mars, STEREO A, Lucy, OSIRIS-APEX, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-06-30T14:35:32Z
## Message ID: 20240630-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-06-29T03:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~885 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 28 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 64/-13 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-06-29T03:36:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-06-29T04:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~506 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 33 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 36/-27 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-06-29T04:00:00-CME-001

3: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-06-29T16:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~809 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 44 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 26/-33 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-06-29T16:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may affect Mars, STEREO A, Lucy (glancing blow), and OSIRIS-APEX (glancing blow). The leading edge of CME with ID: 2024-06-29T03:36:00-CME-001 will reach Mars at 2024-07-03T02:53Z and the flank may give a glancing blow to OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-07-01T10:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The flank of CME with ID: 2024-06-29T16:12:00-CME-001 may give a glancing blow to Lucy at 2024-07-05T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The combined leading edge of all three CMEs may impact STEREO A at 2024-07-02T06:41Z (plus minus 7 hours).

The simulation also indicates that the leading edge of CME with ID 2024-06-29T16:12:00-CME-001 and the flank of CME with ID 2024-06-29T04:00:00-CME-001 may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the combined leading edge or flank of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-07-02T22:06Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: 2024-06-29T03:36:00-CME-001, 2024-06-29T04:00:00-CME-001, 2024-06-29T16:12:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240629_072500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240629_072500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240629_072500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Lucy_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240629_072500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Mars_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240629_072500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Osiris_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

The CME event with ID 2024-06-29T03:36:00-CME-001 is associated with C2.3 flare with ID 2024-06-29T13:08:00-FLR-001 from Active Region 13719 (S18W60) which peaked at 2024-06-29T13:13Z.

The CME event with ID 2024-06-29T16:12:00-CME-001 was predicted to affect STEREO A, Lucy (glancing blow), Mars (glancing blow), and NASA missions near Earth based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20240630-AL-001).

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-06-29T16:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~809 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 44 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 26/-33 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-06-29T16:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A, Lucy (glancing blow), and Mars (glancing blow). The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2024-07-02T08:08Z and the flank may reach Lucy at 2024-07-05T00:00Z and Mars at 2024-07-04T14:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-07-02T21:50Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-06-28T17:07Z.
 
The activity is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-06-28T09:09:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240628-AL-001) which is associated with the arrival of CME with ID 2024-06-25T05:00:00-CME-001 (see notification 20240625-AL-001). The activity is also associated with Geomagnetic Storm with ID 2024-06-28T09:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20240628-AL-002, 20240628-AL-003, 20240628-AL-004, and 20240628-AL-005).

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.
 
Activity ID: 2024-06-28T17:07:00-MPC-001.

## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 7.67 (severe) during the synoptic period 2024-06-28T12:00Z to 2024-06-28T15:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-06-28T09:09:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240628-AL-001) and the arrival of the CME with ID 2024-06-25T05:00:00-CME-001 (see notification 20240625-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-06-28T09:00:00-GST-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 19, 2024 - June 25, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-06-26T22:13:40Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-06-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-06-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240626-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 17 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 12 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-06-25T05:00Z would reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-06-28T14:04Z (plus minus 7 hours) with possible Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20240625-AL-001).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-06-19T06:48Z   Mars at 2024-06-23T00:00Z (glancing blow) and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-21T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240619-AL-002).
2024-06-19T07:00Z   Mars at 2024-06-23T00:00Z (glancing blow) and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-21T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240619-AL-002).
2024-06-21T23:48Z   Psyche at 2024-06-27T18:26Z (see notification 20240622-AL-001).
2024-06-22T02:24Z   Psyche at 2024-06-27T18:26Z (see notification 20240622-AL-001).
2024-06-22T07:12Z   Psyche at 2024-06-30T17:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240622-AL-002).
2024-06-23T07:48Z   Mars at 2024-06-27T01:00Z and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-25T22:14Z (see notification 20240623-AL-003).
2024-06-24T02:48Z   Mars at 2024-06-28T12:00Z (minor impact) and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-27T03:27Z (see notification 20240624-AL-001).
2024-06-24T21:24Z   Mars at 2024-06-29T08:00Z (glancing blow).
2024-06-25T05:00Z   STEREO A at 2024-06-28T03:43Z, Mars at 2024-06-29T00:00Z (glancing blow), and Lucy at 2024-06-30T14:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240625-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.33 during the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. Through the beginning of the reporting period, the energetic electron flux was elevated above background levels, reaching approximately 770 pfu on 2024-06-22. Flux levels later subsided to background levels on 2024-06-23. The observed elevation above background levels was likely associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE and DSCOVR at L1 on 2024-06-17 with the solar wind reaching a maximum sustained speed of approximately 600 km/s.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-06-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-07-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently nine numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13723 (currently located at S19E37) contributed to the numerous M-class flares observed during the reporting period and will likely exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. There may be a slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity on or around 2024-06-28 due to the anticipated arrival of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-06-25T05:00Z as described in the summary above.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-06-25T05:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~556 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 38 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 39/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-06-25T05:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A, Lucy (glancing blow), and Mars (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2024-06-28T03:43Z, Lucy at 2024-06-30T14:00Z, and Mars at 2024-06-29T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-06-28T14:04Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).

2024-06-18T17:24Z    Mars at 2024-06-23T06:00Z (glancing blow) and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-21T16:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240619-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5.33 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5.33 occurred during the synoptic period 2024-06-15T12:00Z-15:00Z. This minor enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-06-15T11:02Z (see notification 20240615-AL-001) and may have been associated with the arrival of a transient event. Note: The Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office has determined that this arrival signature is not associated with the halo CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-06-12T23:48Z. Further information about the analysis of this far-sided halo CME can be found within the CME summary tables included in this report.

The >2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

A solar energetic particle event was detected by STEREO A and SOHO at the start of the reporting period. At STEREO A, the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-06-12T00:21Z (see notifications 20240612-AL-001 and 20240612-AL-002). At SOHO, the flux of the 15.8-39.8 MeV protons channel exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-06-12T02:58Z (see notification 20240612-AL-004). This solar energetic particle event was associated with an O-type CME likely originating from Active Region 13697 after it rotated off the Earth-facing disk and first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-06-11T23:12Z (see notifications 20240612-AL-005 and 20240612-AL-006). The >10 MeV integral proton flux at GOES reached about 9 pfu in response to this activity but remained below the threshold of 10 pfu for the entire reporting period. By 2024-06-16 the enhanced particle environment at SOHO, GOES and STEREO A returned to background levels.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this reporting period due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO and STEREO A described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-06-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-06-25T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently five numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Majority of flaring activity during the reporting period was produced by Active Region 13712 (currently located at S26W36) with some additional flaring from Active Regions 13711 (S11W77) and 13712 (S16W23). These three Active Regions are likely to exhibit notable flaring activity during the outlook period. Active Region 13711 is expected to rotate off the Earth-facing disk on 2024-06-20. Active Regions 13712 and 13713 will continue to traverse the western side of the disk before finally rotating behind the limb by the end of the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. A large northern coronal hole which crossed the central meridian on 2024-06-17 and is currently centered near N45W10 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-06-21.

##

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare, 21 M-class flares, 5 O-type CMEs, and 5 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-06-08T01:53Z would reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-06-10T14:31Z (plus minus 7 hours) with possible Kp index 4-6 (below minor to moderate) (see notification 20240608-AL-010). The arrival of this CME was likely detected at L1 around 2024-06-10T16:36Z (see notification 20240610-AL-005).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-06-08T01:53Z   Lucy at 2024-06-12T20:49Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-06-09T06:57Z, STEREO A at 2024-06-10T04:16Z, Mars at 2024-06-11T16:30Z (glancing blow), OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-10T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240608-AL-010).
2024-06-09T02:37Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2024-06-11T05:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240609-AL-001).
2024-06-10T11:00Z   Mars at 2024-06-14T06:51Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-12T22:50Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-06-11T15:23Z (see notification 20240610-AL-004).
2024-06-10T11:12Z   Mars at 2024-06-14T06:51Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-12T22:50Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-06-11T15:23Z (see notification 20240610-AL-004).
2024-06-10T18:36Z   Mars at 2024-06-14T03:53Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-12T19:04Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-06-11T21:42Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-06-13T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240611-AL-001).
2024-05-28T05:36Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-13T22:00Z (glancing blow), Solar Orbiter at 2024-06-13T16:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240611-AL-002).
2024-06-11T23:12Z   Mars at 2024-06-15T13:02Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-06-14T00:25Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-06-13T03:28Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-06-13T20:27Z, Juno at 2024-06-26T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240612-AL-005 and 20240612-AL-006).

Geomagnetic activity reached moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6.0 during the reporting period. The highest level of Kp = 6.0 occurred during the synoptic period of 2024-06-07T12:00Z-15:00Z (see notifications 20240607-AL-002 and 20240607-AL-003). This moderate enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR at 2024-06-07T10:49Z (see notification 20240607-AL-001). This arrival may be associated with a transient which could have been from coronal dimming signatures seen in EUV imagery on 2024-06-04.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

A solar energetic particle event was detected by SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A. At SOHO, the fluxes of the 15.8-39.8 and 28.2-50.1 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-06-08T03:36Z and 2024-06-08T03:34Z, respectively (see notification 20240608-AL-007). At GOES, the integral flux of the >10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-06-08T02:55Z (see notifications 20240608-AL-005 and 20240608-AL-006) and the integral flux of the >100 MeV protons exceeded 1 pfu starting at 2024-06-08T02:25Z (see notifications 20240608-AL-003 and 20240608-AL-004). At STEREO A, the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-06-08T04:14Z (see notifications 20240608-AL-008 and 20240608-AL-009). This solar energetic particle event was caused by the M3.3 class flare and M9.7 class flare from AR 13697 (S17W68) (see notifications 20240608-AL-001 and 20240608-AL-002) and the O-type CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 at 2024-06-08T01:53Z (see notification 20240608-AL-010). The enhanced particle environment at SOHO, GOES and STEREO A returned to near-background levels by the end of the reporting period.


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this reporting period due to the solar energetic particle event and geomagnetic activity described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-06-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-06-18T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor to high levels during the outlook period. There are currently five active regions on the Earth-facing disk. The highest level flaring observed during the reporting period came from AR 13697 which rotated off the Earth-facing disk on 2024-06-10. This active region recently produced a far-sided eruption with associated O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-06-11T23:12Z (see notifications 20240612-AL-005 and 20240612-AL-006) that caused an increase in solar energetic particles at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A. A solar energetic particle event was detected by SOHO and STEREO A. At SOHO, the flux of the 15.8-39.8 MeV proton channel exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-06-12T02:58Z (see notification 20240612-AL-004). At STEREO A, the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-06-12T00:21Z (see notifications 20240612-AL-001 and 20240612-AL-002). The enhanced particle environment at SOHO remains elevated above threshold, while the enhanced particle environment at GOES and STEREO A are currently elevated but below their respective thresholds.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low to moderate levels during the outlook period. There is a coronal hole centered near S45W40 that may become geoeffective in the next few days. Another coronal hole centered near N05E23 is expected to cross the central meridian on 2024-06-15 and may reach geoeffective longitudes by the end of the outlook period.

The CME will be analyzed once more coronagraph imagery becomes available. 

Solar energetic particle event has also been detected at STEREO A starting at 2024-06-12T00:21Z (see notification 20240612-AL-002).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 4 X-class flares, 19 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 11 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-05-29T14:48Z may give NASA missions near Earth a glancing blow at 2024-06-01T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with possible Kp index 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20240529-AL-005). This CME was not detected at L1. 

Additionally, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-06-01T20:00Z may give NASA missions near Earth a glancing blow at 2024-06-04T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with possible Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20240602-AL-002). Analysis to determine if this CME was detected at L1 between 2024-06-04 and 2024-06-05 is currently ongoing. 

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-05-29T14:48Z    Psyche at 2024-06-04T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240529-AL-005).
2024-05-29T17:36Z    Psyche at 2024-06-05T22:03Z (see notification 20240530-AL-001).
2024-05-30T03:48Z    Psyche at 2024-06-06T15:04Z (see notification 20240530-AL-002).
2024-05-30T09:24Z    Psyche at 2024-06-06T15:04Z (see notification 20240530-AL-002).
2024-06-01T19:12Z    Solar Orbiter at 2024-06-03T16:23Z (see notification 20240602-AL-001).
2024-06-01T20:00Z    STEREO A at 2024-06-04T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240602-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity reached minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4.67 during the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4.67 was initially observed during the synoptic period 2024-05-31T03:00Z to 2024-05-31T06:00Z and may have been associated with the arrival of a weak transient event detected by ACE and DSCOVR at L1 early on 2024-05-31. The highest value of Kp = 4.67 was observed again later in the reporting period during the synoptic period 2024-06-03T21:00Z to 2024-06-04T00:00Z and may have been associated with the arrival of another possible transient event detected by ACE and DSCOVR at L1 at 2024-06-03T21:28Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-06-05T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-06-11T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate to high levels during the outlook period. There are currently twelve numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13697 (currently located at S18W32) produced 5 X-class flares and numerous M-class flares since it rotated onto the Earth-facing disk on 2024-05-28 and will likely continue to exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period. It is highly suspected that this Active Region is the previously numbered Active Region 13664, which was responsible for numerous X-class and M-class flares observed during prior reporting periods.  

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A narrow coronal hole feature currently centered around N15W12 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-06-07.

Estimated speed: ~898 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 27 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -24/-14 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-06-01T20:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A (glancing blow). The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth.
